body_text.text: ABSTRACT 23 In social species where offspring are reared together in communal burrows or similar 24 structures, young animals typically do not engage in between-group contact during their 25 developmenta behavioural trait we call 'offspring with restricted between-group contact' 26 (ORC). The impact of this trait on the persistence of contagious pathogens that generate 27 lifelong immunity in their hosts is currently unclear. We hypothesize that in populations with 28 ORC, the formation, in groups, of a 'protective barrier' of only recovered adults, prevents the 29 transmission of this type of pathogens to the new susceptible hosts (i.e. young animals), 30 thereby increasing the probability of epidemic fade-out. We implement a spatially implicit 31 individual-based Susceptible-Infected-Recovered (SIR) model for a large range of host and 32 pathogen traits and show that the epidemic fade-out probability is consistently higher in 33 populations with ORC, especially when disease spread is fast (high basic reproduction 34 number R0). We also show that ORC can counteract the cost of group-living in terms of 35 disease risk to a greater extent than variation in other traits. We discuss our findings in INTRODUCTION 42 Pathogens of infectious diseases that spread through direct contact or physical proximity can 43 imperil species that live in dense populations or large social groups, including humans, 44 livestock or wildlife (Altizer et al. 2003 . 53 A social network can further be characterized by its modularity, that is, its degree of division 54 into modules such as social groups (e.g. clans, prides or troops) or subgroups (e.g. age classes 55 in the case of eusocial insects, Stroeymeyt et al. 2018 , also see Griffin and Nunn 2012, Sah et 56 al. 2017). Generally, a social network is considered to be highly modular, or to have a high 57 'community structure' (White et al. 2017 ) when individuals within one module are more 58 connected to each other than they are to individuals in other modules (Newman 2006 ). It has 59 been hypothesized that a highly modular social network can generally reduce disease risk in 60 group-living animals (Griffin and Nunn 2012, Nunn et al. 2015 ). Yet this view has been 61 recently challenged by a study which found that the beneficial effects of modularity on 62 disease fade-out are restricted to extreme cases of exceptionally high modularity, which are 63 rarely observed in natural systems (Sah et al. 2017) . 64 Here we investigate how highly modular social networks characterized by age-dependent networks where young animals have no contact with members of other groups, and term this 67 life history trait 'offspring with restricted between-group contact' (ORC). 68 In contrast to most ungulate species for instance, in which precocial young follow their 69 mother shortly after birth (Lent 1974) , several group-living species rear their offspring in 70 communal burrows, nurseries, crèches or family groups within group territories or home 71 ranges for extended periods of time, during which time young rarely if ever contact 72 individuals of other groups. This includes for instance spotted hyenas Crocuta crocuta 73 (Kruuk 1972), African lions Panthera leo (Schaller 1972) or European rabbits Oryctolagus 74 cuniculus (Daly 1981). 75 Restricting contact of young animals with individuals of other groups may specifically limit 76 the persistence of pathogens that induce lifelong immunity following infection. Such Here we used an individual-based model to investigate for the first time this second 96 mechanism and test the prediction that the probability of epidemic fade-out increases in 97 populations (i.e. networks) of social species with an ORC trait. For this purpose, we 98 developed an SIR model to describe pathogen transmission and host population dynamics. In 99 order to assess how consistently the probability of epidemic fade-out increased due to ORC, 100 we systematically varied parameters likely to influence pathogen transmission dynamics: (1) 101 host birth rate, (2) host death rate (which occurs independently of infection), (3) contact rates 102 between members of different groups, (4) infection rate at contact, (5) individual infection 103 length, (6) virulence (i.e. the increase in host death rate due to infection), and (7) whether 104 transmission is frequency or density-dependent. For each specific combination of parameters, 105 we investigated two scenarios. First, we set up a baseline scenario in which rates of between-106 group contact were identical for individuals of all ages. Second, we investigated an ORC 107 scenario in which individuals below a given age-threshold could not contact members of 108 other groups, i.e. their rates of between-group contact were set to zero. This is simulating the 109 legal requirements of confinement put into action by authorities to limit the spread of 110 pandemics, e.g. during the COVID-19 pandemic; the closure of schools and prevention of 111 contact between young and elderly people, including within households (e.g. Anderson et al. 112 2020, Kelvin and Halperin 2020). Because ORC decreases R0, we adjusted the infection rate 113 in the baseline scenario such that the value of R0 was always identical in both scenarios to 114 insure that the emergence of a more efficient immunity barrier are directly related to the ORC 115 trait, and not to its mediated effect on R0. We discuss our results in relation to behavioural mechanisms yielding herd immunity as well as the likely outcomes of altering social network 117 modularity through management measures.

Model description 120 The model description followed the ODD (Overview, Design concepts, Details) protocol for 121 describing individual-and agent-based models (Grimm et al. 2006 , Grimm et al. 2010 ). The The purpose of our model was to study how disease dynamics in group-living species are 130 affected by an 'offspring with restricted between-group contact' (ORC) trait, which occurs 131 when offspring are kept in subunits or 'modules' such as communal dens and burrows, 132 crèches or family groups within their social groups, until they reach the age at which they can 133 start engaging in between-group interactions. Understanding the patterns of transmission and the mechanisms of persistence of 46 such diseases in group-living species is thus of key relevance for human public health, 47 economy or wildlife conservation. The structure of social contact networks in group-living 48 species may critically influence the spread and persistence of contagious diseases (Kappeler 49 et al. 2015). For example, if a social network contains a few central individuals who are 50 exceptionally well connected to others, then these individuals can act as super-spreaders and 51 their presence can strongly increase the likelihood and extent of an epidemic as well as the 52 persistence of pathogens (Lloyd-Smith et al. 2005)

FIGREF1.text: 77 pathogens, which include many viruses such as measles and canine distemper virus in the 78 genus Morbilivirus, mumps in the genus Rubulavirus or rubella in the genus Rubivirus 79 (Morris et al. 2015) rely on the birth of new susceptible hosts and their transmission to young 80 individuals to persist in a host population (Lloyd-Smith et al. 2005). 81 An ORC trait could affect pathogen persistence via at least two, mutually non-exclusive, 82 mechanisms. First, as a rather trivial effect, by restricting contact of young animals with 83 members of other groups, ORC could directly reduce the probability of disease spread and 84 hence also the basic reproduction number R0 of a pathogen, which is the expected number of 85 secondary infections that a single infected host causes in a population of susceptible 86 individuals (McCallum et al. 2001). Second, ORC could increase the chance of epidemic 87 fade-out by depriving the pathogen of access to susceptible individuals during the late stage 88 of an epidemic. Indeed, when most adults in the population have become immune (and thus 89 herd immunity (see e.g. Anderson and May 1985) is high, the chance of pathogen spread to 90 mostly susceptible young animals would be substantially curtailed. In other words, ORC may 91 increase the efficiency of a protective barrier in groups composed of only recovered

Our results suggest that the formation of protective barriers composed of recovered adults 373 around the new generation of susceptible juveniles (i.e. 'sealed groups') is the likely 374 mechanism by which disease persistence is reduced in the population (figure 5 (b)). This 375 phenomenon is expected to emerge during the late stage of an epidemic, when a high herd 376 immunity, i.e. a high proportion of recovered individuals in the population (John and Samuel 377 2000), protects the new generation of susceptible juveniles from infection (Fine et al. 2011).

In accordance with the previous findings of 388 Griffin and Nunn (2012) and of Nunn et al. (2015), who showed that when the structuring 389 emerged from restricted contacts within groups, modularity slowed the spread of disease and 390 reduced maximum prevalence, we found that highly modular social networks can reduce 391 disease spread and persistence in group-living animals whose between-group contacts are 392 restricted according to individual age. Sah et al. (2017) found that network modularity limited 393 disease spread only when modularity was very high, i.e. when individuals within one module 394 were more connected to each other than they were to individuals in other modules (Newman 395 2006). Here we showed that an ORC trait had a particularly positive effect for the host 396 population in terms of epidemic fade-out for hosts with a high contact ratio, hence in 397 networks of initially low modularity (figure 3). When the contact ratio was high, the pathogen 398 could more easily spread between groups and was less likely to die out quickly; thus 399 restricting offspring's between-group contact could bring more benefits than when the 400 contact ratio was low. These findings differ from those of Sah et al. (2017) possibly because 401 we modelled host population dynamics. FIGREF16.text: , interventions focusing specifically on individuals bridging the modular 408 network structure (i.e. with high between group contacts) may often be more efficient 409 (Salathé and Jones 2010). Such 'bridging' individuals could be dispersing individuals in the 410 case of rabies in foxes or raccoons (Reynolds et al. 2015), bovine tuberculosis (bTB) in 411 badgers (Weber et al. 2013) or Classical Swine Fever (CSF) in wild boars (Scherer et al. 412 2020). Neglecting the potentially important influence of between-group interactions on 413 disease spread, in combination with the disturbance of populations through persecution and 414 hunting, may have been responsible for the failure of disease elimination programmes for 415 bTB (Vial and Donnelly 2011) or CSF in Germany (Scherer et al. 2019). Our results also 416 corroborate the so-called 'network frailty concept', showing the importance of immunization 417 of highly connected individuals rather than random vaccinations as a management measure 418 (Ferrari et al. 2006) and more generally, the need to consider the network structure of the 419 underlying biological systems. 420 The ORC trait mimicked the case of hosts with clearly defined social units (e.g. groups) 421 where offspring are reared together, thus have high contact rates with their own group 422 members but no contact to members of other groups during their development. This 423 definition suggests a spatial separation of the groups and clearly defined 'nesting' locations 424 spaced at some distance, such as communal dens or burrows. In the Patagonian mara 425 Dolichotis patagonum for instance, several pairs of adults cluster their young together in a 426 crèche (Taber 1987, Ganslosser and Wehnelt 1997) (see

FIGREF17.text: ducks Somateria mollissima, juveniles from different broods are raised 432 together and guarded by adult females (McKinnon et al. 2006, Öst et al. 2007). It is likely 433 that juveniles in such systems are more exposed to pathogens deposited by conspecifics in the 434 environment (as some pathogens may survive several hours outside their hosts), as opposed 435 to juveniles who are stationary in communal dens or burrows for a relatively long proportion 436 of their lifespan. In contrast, colonial nesters, bird flocks, seabird colonies or the large herds 437 of most ungulates such as zebras Equus quagga, wildebeest Connochaetes, bison Bison bison 438 or caribou Rangifer tarandus show low network modularity. These species are likely to fit 439 with the outcomes found in the 'baseline scenario', i.e. with no age structure in betweenmodel, individuals surviving pathogen infection acquired lifelong immunity. One 442 typical example of such a pathogen in group-forming wildlife is canine distemper virus 443 (CDV) (Appel and Summers 1995) or the now eradicated rinderpest (Daszak et al. 2000). 444 Both morbiliviruses are highly contagious and some strains can cause massive mortality in 445 wildlife. For example, a CDV epidemic in East Africa in 1993/1994 caused important 446 declines of African lion and spotted hyena populations (Roelke-Parker 1996, Marescot et al. 447 2018, Benhaiem et al. 2018). CDV infects a broad range of mammals, mostly carnivores 448 (Beineke, Baumgärtner, & Wohlsein, 2015, Deem, Spelman, Yates, & Montali, 2000). Even 449 though many viruses are expected to induce lifelong immunity in their hosts, immunity can 450 actually wane over time or provide only incomplete protection against reinfection (Morris et 451 al. 2015). This is often difficult to verify in wild, free-ranging populations, as it requires 452 repeated serological samples to measure antibody levels even in old animals. Even so,
